snapshots incremental yes so the first time let's see you one tab Drive the first time you call snapshot the 200
gigs you're using will be backed up block by block into S3 um let's say you make 30 gigs of changes so this now
subset has been changed um and you call snapshot again we're only going to back up the 30 gigs of changes right so and
every snapshot we make after that will be an incremental from the last now what's interesting about that is then
somebody is asked me this as a follow on question what happens if I delete the first snapshot you know doesn't that destroy all the incrementals no because
what we do is we maintain a database of which blocks belong to which snapshots
um you know that are still active so if you deleted a you know uh the the root snapshot the first snapshot and there
was a block um in there that changed in the second snapshot and you didn't want that root snapshot then we could delete
that one block but we can't delete the rest of it because there's many blocks that still belong to a recovered second snapshot so we'll maintain that
consistency and understand at a block level which one belong to which snapshots so we don't accidentally delete or corrupt your your
volumes

yes no so the question was if somebody accidentally deletes a file in S3 uh do
we have a way to recover that the answer is no um so we're faithful to your delete command um
so actually some customers ask us the flip question they say how do I ensure that you really delete it and it's like no no we really delete it we don't hold
on to it for later um thinking maybe you want it back uh so there's there's ways you can protect against that um if it's
a small number of files you can enable a feature called secure delete that literally requires that you have a multiactor off token um like a a key fob
and you do it through the console and type in a six-digit number to delete it right I wouldn't do that for everything because it can only be done by person
and so if you had thousands of files like that and you want to delete them all you'd have a lot of busy people with keep BS running around um there's also a
versioning feature um that allows you to uh actually enable versioning for a file
or a bucket and what that does is when you call delete it will delete the most recent version so when someone tries to
hit that key it'll be gone but you can recover the last version which actually is the same as the most recent so we
always keep a version ID against it there's the generic one you know the no version ID which points to the most
recent and then if you delete it it just all it does is clears that out so your most recent still there but if you
access it with the version ID You're Expecting right so you can get it back through that feature as well um so
there's two two kind of approaches to that M you can also turn off delete right so you can also use an I am user
an identity and access management user for all of your S3 access and then you can literally disable the delete command
